results.title: Jenny
results.creator_credit: Patricia Phillips, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wednesday’s children”.
Part of a series of six short dramas for adolescents and adults on teenage alienation, Jenny is the story of a seemingly tough seventeen-year-old who is arrested for trafficking drugs. Jenny’s story emerges as she is interviewed by a skilful social worker. Her unemployed, alcoholic father has been sexually abusing her, and is now turning his attention to her weaker, younger sister as well.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Patricia Phillips, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Vicky
results.creator_credit: Elsa Bolam, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wednesday’s children”.
One of a series of six short dramas for adolescents and adults about teenage alienation. An unhappy suburban teenager whose affluent parents don’t get along, Vicki turns to an older man and a life of crime. Scenes in Vicky’s home clearly show the lack of communication between her parents, and between them and the girl.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Elsa Bolam, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Webwurld
results.credit_line:
Jess Johnson and Simon Ward

Single-channel video work

ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Soundtrack by Andrew Clarke. video, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Webwurld appears like fragments of a dream, mesmerising its viewers with a cosmic, otherworldly dimension that seems to stretch out in every direction.

constellations_primary.name: Webwurlds
constellations_primary.description: Jess Johnson and Simon Ward's work is inspired by science fiction and fantasy. Johnson's hand-drawn illustrations are heavily detailed with geometric patterns and incorporate anthropomorphic characters amongst architectural environments in immersive other worlds.

constellations_other.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_other.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.description:
Webwurld appears like fragments of a dream, mesmerising its viewers with a cosmic, otherworldly dimension that seems to stretch out in every direction. Working from Jess Johnsonâ€™s complex hand-drawn images, video artist Simon Ward rebirths her 2D images as chimerical 3D animations.

“My drawings are meshworks of cultural symbology, humanoid clones, messianic figures and alien runes placed in architectural settings. This practice feeds into installations and collaborations in animation, music, fashion, virtual reality and textile art. These additional mediums bring the world of my drawings into physical and virtual spaces, providing an immersive experience for audiences.” â€“ Jess Johnson
description_for_label:
Webwurld appears like fragments of a dream, mesmerising its viewers with a cosmic, otherworldly dimension that seems to stretch out in every direction. Working from Jess Johnsonâ€™s complex hand-drawn images, video artist Simon Ward rebirths her 2D images as chimerical 3D animations.

“My drawings are meshworks of cultural symbology, humanoid clones, messianic figures and alien runes placed in architectural settings. This practice feeds into installations and collaborations in animation, music, fashion, virtual reality and textile art. These additional mediums bring the world of my drawings into physical and virtual spaces, providing an immersive experience for audiences.” â€“ Jess Johnson

results.title: We Dream of Networks
results.credit_line:
Jess Johnson
Limited edition print
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: giclÃ©e print on archival quality cotton rag with four deckled edges, edition 40/50
results.brief_description:
Jess Johnson was born in Aotearoa/New Zealand in 1979, and lives and works in New York. Her drawing and installation practice is influenced by science fiction, language, culture and technology. In her drawings she depicts complex worlds that combine densely layered patterns, objects and figures within architectural settings. Johnsonâ€™s drawings are often displayed within constructed environments that act as physical portals into her speculative worlds. Her video collaborations with Simon Ward have involved translating her drawings into animated Virtual Reality, thus enabling her audience to have the simulated experience of entering the hypnotic realms depicted in her drawings. Jess Johnsonâ€™s work has been exhibited Internationally in solo exhibitions at; Jack Hanley Gallery, New York; Art Basel, Hong Kong; Nanzuka Gallery, Tokyo; Talbot Rice Gallery, Edinburgh; National Gallery of Australia; Museum of Contemporary Art, Australia; Auckland Art Gallery and Christchurch Art Gallery, New Zealand.

Jess Johnson is represented by Darren Knight Gallery, Sydney; Ivan Anthony Gallery, Auckland and Jack Hanley Gallery, New York

results.title: The Rigid Heddle Frame
results.creator_credit: John Gray, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Weaving”.
An instructional film on weaving for both beginners and more advanced weavers. In the rigid heddle frame, warp threads are passed through a slotted, wooden heddle instead of being attached to moving cords. Additional credits: photographer: Alan Grice ; script: Kay Donald ; editor: David Corke ; weaver and adviser: Erika Semler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Gray, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media

results.title: Table looms
results.creator_credit: John Gray, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Weaving”
An instructional film on weaving for both beginners and more advanced weavers. Shows samples of cloth which can be made on multi-shaft looms such as the table loom.

results.creator_credit: John Gray, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia

Episode of Series “Weaving”.
A simple instructional program on weaving for both beginners and more advanced weavers. Shows ways of making looms from simple and inexpensive materials.
